citations.narrative:
The emergency action plan addresses animal escapes and human emergencies, but has not been updated to a hazards
based approach, including fires and natural disasters as required by the Animal Welfare Act. Contingency plans must
identify emergencies such as electrical outages, faulty HVAC systems, fires, mechanical breakdowns and natural
disasters most likely to be experienced by the facility in order to provide for the welfare of the covered animals.
Correct by 31 August 2023.

The perimeter fence for the "D" group of enclosures, including lions, tigers, hybrids and wolves does not meet the 8 foot
fence requirement for potentially dangerous animals. In several areas the perimeter fence is approximately 7 feet 6 inches
to 7 feet 9 inches high, adjacent to the lockouts used by the potentially dangerous animals. Perimeter fences must be
maintained so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going
through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility.
Correct by 31 August 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the President and manager.
Additional Inspectors:
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
